title: Extinct Types
content:
I am looking for a typeface to use for a design on extinct species (of mammals)  
Any suggestions on a font which may have suffered a similar fate as the dodo or thylacine?

Warrent
author: warrent

comments.content:
\> _a font which may have suffered a similar fate as the dodo_

The trouble with using an “extinct” typeface is that they are, well… _extinct_ ;-)

I suggest using Folkwang, by H. Schardt(1949) if you can find it.

How about an Adobe version of a Berthold font?

Cheers, Si

Any multiple-master.

Seriously: Neuland? Maybe a bit cliche though. Hey, what about Vendetta?

hhp
now if the font were extinct, you coudn’t really use it, could you? Is phototype still alive?

\> _Is phototype still alive?_

Thanks to the folks at [Incipit](http://web.archive.org/web/20061116104401/http:/www.incipit.com/linkrefs2.html) you can still have heads set from film fonts.

“_Incipit has one of the largest libraries of display faces, more than 3,500 individual fonts on film._”

Extinct Animal to Typeface

Dodo \> Didi  
Thylacine (whatever it is?) \> Thiamine or Thymesans

\>now if the font were extinct, you coudn’t really use it, could you?

The problem is that even with all the ancient technology used for typesetting and printing there are hobyists or developing world print shops still using them - so they are not extinct. Or the technologies are so obscure that they were never really popular in the first place - so DOA not extinct.

Could you show extinction by choosing a typeface that is somehow incomplete? FontFont has a good selection of distressed and broken fonts. Then there’s [Sketchy Times](http://web.archive.org/web/20061116104401/http:/www.exclamachine.com/) by Choz Cunningham.

I assume you are just looking for a display face.

BTW: a dodo is not an extinct mammal.
